The importance of the 2020 Census
The 2020 Census is quickly approaching and filling out the form is very important for our state and our school district in order to receive federal funding for education, health, and housing programs. The census count will impact federal funding for the following in education:
1. Special education
2. Head Start
3. Classroom technology
4. Food assistance, including free & reduced lunch
5. Maternal & child health programs

The census goes live on March 12 and residents can begin filling out the 9 question questionnaire at that time. Residents can complete the questionnaire in three different ways:
1. Online
2. By phone
3. Complete the paper form

It is important to remember to count everyone living in the household, including children of all ages. All answers on the questionnaire are 100% confidential and may not be shared with anyone.
I hope you will take the time to complete the Census 2020 questionnaire when it becomes available on March 12.

post_text: More on Chronic Absenteeism: National data from 2015-16 found that nearly 8 million students were chronically absent (10% or at least 18 days). That was 800,000 more chronic absenteeism students than in 2013-14. In Clarenceville School District in 2015-16 school year 271 students missed 10% or more of the school year (14.7% district-wide average). The state of Michigan's data in 2015-16 was 27.8% chronically absent (1 in 4 students or 419,755 students). We must work together to support one another to better understand the importance of attendance in school and the effects absenteeism has on learning now and in the future. We must meet this challenge together.

How do we start to defeat chonic absenteeism in schools...We show the value of an education by "Making Every Day Count." We can demonstrate the importance of attendance by encouraging the following:

Be on time, every time
Build backup plans or a buddy system for getting to and from school
Plan vacations when school is out
Set appointments (medical, dental, etc.) before or after school

Let's work together to show we value education.

post_text: Chronic absenteeism is a challenge for school districts. Missing school 10 or more days a year has severe learning consequences. The research suggests that missing more than 5 days of kindergarten makes learning to read harder. Students who miss 10% or more of school are more likely to not graduate on time or at all. Being late to school or leaving early is a precursor to poor attendance. We must work to help our students understand the importance of school and to value their learning. We must make every day count. Let's work together to end chronic absenteeism.

post_text: Here is an update on the ongoing measles outbreak in Oakland & Wayne counties as provided by the Michigan Department of Health & Human Services.
shared_text:
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
April 8, 2019 at 5:25 PM ·

⚠️ Measles outbreak reaches 41 cases in Michigan. The newly confirmed cases were in Oakland and Washtenaw counties, bringing the case count to 39 in Oakland County, one in Washtenaw County and one in Wayne County. Infected individuals range in age from 8 months to 63 years. MDHHS is working closely with Public Health Oakland and Washtenaw County Health Department to identify possible exposure locations for these latest cases. Known exposure sites in Oakland County are listed at Oakgov.com/health. Washtenaw County exposure locations will be added to washtenaw.org/health as they become known. There are no public exposure sites for the Wayne County case.
We urge you to contact your healthcare provider or local health department about getting vaccinated for measles. A complete listing of local health departments is available at Malph.org/resources/directory.
The Washtenaw County Health Department is hosting a walk-in vaccination clinic on April 9, 9 a.m. – 7 p.m. and on April 10, 5 to 7 p.m. at 555 Towner Street in Ypsilanti.

(Julie Ntagazwa, Mark Popkov, Elijah Stewart, Mikayla Williams, and Clara Willis). We are proud of all of you!! (Historical Perspective: The Young Inventors Program began in the Clarenceville School District 8 years ago and has now been developed into a program for four surrounding school districts in our area.)
